numbered_ace_sentences: 1. The graph standardizes the scale of responses.
2. The graph uses percentages.
3. The graph does not simply count the number of responses.
4. This allows a comparison between men and women.
5. I appreciate this comparison.
6. This makes the graph more digestible for non-statisticians.
7. The graph orders three methods of reaching out.
8. This ordering conveys the most common ways that these young adults reach out to their parents.
9. Women reach out to their parents at higher rates than men.
10. I wonder why women reach out to their parents at higher rates than men.
11. I wonder how this difference reflects the relationship that parents have with their female children.
12. I wonder how this difference reflects the relationship that parents have with their male children.
13. I wonder how we could incorporate other questions into the survey.
14. These questions concern communication with a parent.
15. One such question is about how qualitative the children believe their communication with their parent is.
16. I am a college student.
17. I struggle with making time to contact my parents.
18. I do not do this on purpose.
19. Because of this, I feel that I cannot have the most interesting conversations with my parents.
20. I believe that it is nice to check in with my parents when I can.
21. I am away at college.
22. I wonder how many survey respondents are college students.
23. I wonder how being a college student affects how often a respondent reaches out to the respondent's parents.
24. The headline is: Parents Back Home: Are You Staying In Touch?
